Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Surface State Studies of Topological Insulators/Superconductors
Award.AbstractNarration:
****Technical Abstract****
This CAREER grant supported by the Division Materials Research aims to have a crystal growth of new and perfect topological insulators/superconductors and exploration of Dirac surface state of the perfectly grown topological insulators (TIs). It also aims to integrate research in experimental condensed matter physics and development of a unique physics educational program at Missouri University of Science and Technology (S&T). New methods will be used to grow perfect bulk insulating TIs and to fabricate large surface-to-volume ratio of TI nanowire arrays. These perfect topological materials are necessary for Dirac surface current detection which is important for both new physics exploration such as studies of Majorana fermion and axion electrodynamics, and technological applications such as spintronic and quantum computing devices. Shubnikov-de Haas oscillations, Aharonov-Bohm effect and Altshuler-Aronov-Spivak interference on the perfectly grown TIs will be performed to estimate surface Dirac electron effective mass and decay length. Surface resistivity measurements under magnetic fields up to 45 T will then be carried out for the investigation of fractional quantum Hall effect which is a big quest in the field concerning the role of interactions and strong correlations in topological states of matter.

****Non-Technical Abstract****
Topological insulator (TI) is a new quantum material which has insulating property in its bulk but has high conductivity of electrons on its surface. This surface conducting state is predicted to be a solution for future computing technology. However, surface transport measurements are challenging due to the imperfections of the current existing TIs. A new synthesis technique that utilizes a reduced confining reaction space will be applied to grow perfect bulk insulating crystals in order to permit surface current detection. This electronic transport detection of the surface electrons or the surface Dirac state is necessary for heat dissipation-less spintronic devices where electron spin manipulation can be performed by interfacing a perfect TI and a superconductor for potential fault-tolerant quantum computing applications. Besides, TIs can act as a bridge to bring together high energy and condensed matter physicists to search for long-sought particle such as the Majorana fermion i.e. a fermion which is its own anti-particle and an intermediate particle for electric and magnetic field interactions called the axion which could provide a clue to the mystery of dark matter in cosmology. This CAREER grant also helps to integrate the material synthesis in solid state physics course taught in S&T and to present physics shows targeted to local K-12 students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Three-dimensional topological insulators have been found to depict topological distinct phases of matter and have attracted great interest due to helical spin texture on the surfaces. This helical spin surface state could lead to an interesting phenomenon called the quantum spin Hall effect. Not surprisingly these new materials have spawned great attention in the science community because of potential of interesting applications and scientific explorations. Inducing magnetism in topological insulators can create new platforms for magnetic monopole detection, which could shed light on dark matter and dark energy, and hence verify axion electrodynamics theory. On the other hand, inducing superconductivity in the materials could give rise to a new quantum phase called topological superconductor, which wiould be a promising system for quantum computer applications. In order for the materials to be used in technological applications or scientific studies, high quality crystalline materials are neccessary for detecting the spin surface states by electrical transport measurements.

High quality crystals of topological insulators/superconductors and magnetic doped topological insulators have been successfully grown for the surface state detections. The new method i.e. the two-step vacuum quartz sealing method was successfully developed to grow crystals of nearly perfect bulk insulating topological insulators (TIs). The work is important for new physics exploration such as studies of the surface state, topological superconductivity and axion electrodynamics. Transport and torque magnetometry measurements on the crystals were performed at high magnetic fields and low temperatures. The results of the angular dependence of the Shubnikov-de Haas (SdH) and de Haas-van Alphen (dHA) quantum oscillations were obtained to enable the determination of the Fermi surfaces of the materials. These have provided better understanding of the new phases of the grown crystals in condensed matter physics.

Antiferromagnetism can be induced in Bi2Se3 TIs by intercalation of Fe cations. Antifferomagnetism is considered to be a broken symmetry state which the translation symmetry and the time reversal symmetry are broken. However, antiferromagntism in a topological insulator is predicted to preserve the combination of the two symmetries. There is still lack of antiferromagnetic TI which can show the property of the invariance of the combination of the two symmetries. FexBi2Se3 is considered a potential candidate for the studies. Cr-doping can induce ferromagnetism in Sb2Te3 TI with Tc ~ 170 K. In addition, anomalous Hall effect was observed in the bulk Cr0.2Sb2Te3 crystals. This system would ideally serve as good platform for spin Hall effect study. The magnetic TIs would also provide promising platforms for magnetic monopole research and axion electrodynamics studies.

By Nb-doping in bismuth selenide, the TI turns into a type-II bulk superconductor while maintaining its helical metallic surface state in its normal state. However, at high magnetic field this doped TI behaves superparamagnetically. Niobium is usually considered a non-magnetic cation but it exhibits a unique magnetic behavior in this doped TI. Magnetic susceptibility of the TI shows paramagnetic behavior at high field due to destruction of the superconductivity which is the underlying bases for ferromagnetic coupling of Nb moments. The discovery of the superconducting NbxBi2Se3 has brought a great impact to the scientific community. A few theoretical works have been performed and the outcomes have led to an understanding that superconductivity can induce ferromagnetism. In addition, the coexistence of the magnetism and superconductivity in NbxBi2Se3 could lead to the first realization of topological superconductivity which has been a long sought material in condensed matter physics community. This system will also provide a platform for investigating exotic surface excitation i.e. Majorana fermionic bound state which is of interest to elementary particle physics research groups and quantum computing research community.

Thin films with atomic layer thickness have attracted much interest in condensed matter physics and materials science communities. However, it is still challenging in fabricating atomic layered films or nanostructures without lengthy and complicated processes. For examples, thin film growth by chemical vapor deposition can be a long process. Atomic layered crystalline materials obtained by mechanical exfoliation or Scotch tape method can be problem due to contamination. The method of exfoliating layered crystalline material utilizing electric field provides a fast and clean way in obtaining atomic layers of quantum materials. The electric field exfoliation of crystalline materials will be useful and benefit to researchers who are interested in electronic device fabrications.

Physics demonstrations to K-12 students, teachers and parents were performed in the Family Fun Night at Rolla Middle School from 2014 to 2018. This year, the event has attracted 300 students. The Family Fun night has successfully provided exposure to science and technology for young people, teachers, or other members of the public.
